retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req007
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer:  The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transferrable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. In addition to the core lab and lecture coursework covering the major industry areas of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry, the program incorporates a core course entitled “Biotechnology Products and Regulation.” This course takes a critical look at industry from the initial stages of research and development in the biomedical sciences through the legal and regulatory stages of biotechnology product development and manufacturing. This content is key to understanding how the biotech industry functions and thus is a centerpiece in your training in our degree program. Finally, you are required to enroll in a minimum of one graduate biotech seminar course. While the specific content of the seminar courses will vary to reflect the dynamics of the ever-changing biotech field, the two typical focus areas of the semester-long seminars will be “Instrumentation in the Biotech Industry” and “Cutting edge topics in the Biotech Industry today”.

Key Points: team-based lab courses

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo003
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What legal and regulatory understanding is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Successfully employ knowledge of the regulatory and legal framework that underpins the field of industrial biotechnology, including knowledge of pre-clinical and clinical product development, relevant US government regulations and laws, and intellectual property concerns.

Key Points: regulatory and legal framework

model_answer: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products.

Question: What is the Accelerated Master’s Option in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Accelerated Master’s programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree.

Key Points: graduate coursework; undergraduate students

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req007
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer:  The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transferrable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. In addition to the core lab and lecture coursework covering the major industry areas of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry, the program incorporates a core course entitled “Biotechnology Products and Regulation.” This course takes a critical look at industry from the initial stages of research and development in the biomedical sciences through the legal and regulatory stages of biotechnology product development and manufacturing. This content is key to understanding how the biotech industry functions and thus is a centerpiece in your training in our degree program. Finally, you are required to enroll in a minimum of one graduate biotech seminar course. While the specific content of the seminar courses will vary to reflect the dynamics of the ever-changing biotech field, the two typical focus areas of the semester-long seminars will be “Instrumentation in the Biotech Industry” and “Cutting edge topics in the Biotech Industry today”.

Key Points: team-based lab courses

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req020
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the relationship between core courses and elective courses in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Core courses build foundational knowledge, while electives allow students to apply and expand that knowledge.

Key Points: Core foundation; Electives expand knowledge

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req016
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What does each credit in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program represent in academic work?

Answer: Each credit represents about three hours of academic work per week, including class and independent study.

Key Points: ~3 hours academic work per credit

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req006
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?

Answer: After completion of 9 credits in the MS Biotechnology program, students are required to enroll in at least one credit under Capstone Experience: BIOT 891, BIOT 892, BIOT 895, or BIOT 889. The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator and will be consistent with your career development plans.

Key Points: 9 credits

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req004
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many elective credits are required in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students complete between 8 and 14 elective credits.

Key Points: 8–14 elective credits

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req001
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Full-time students can complete the program in 18 months. Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor’s degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program. Students choosing the project or internship track would undertake an internship or internships in industry, applied research in an industrial job where the student is already employed, or research in a faculty member’s laboratory at UNH. Students choosing the co-op work experience route would spend 6 months in a full-time industrial placement as part of their degree program.

Key Points: 18 months; Accelerated Master's program in 12 months

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req002
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?

Answer: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and a Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

Key Points: 30 credits; 4 Core Curriculum courses

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo003
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What legal and regulatory understanding is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Successfully employ knowledge of the regulatory and legal framework that underpins the field of industrial biotechnology, including knowledge of pre-clinical and clinical product development, relevant US government regulations and laws, and intellectual property concerns.

Key Points: regulatory and legal framework

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req015
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the main goal of the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: To successfully undertake a substantial Capstone experience (in industry or in an academic laboratory) in which the student demonstrates sufficient knowledge of the professional, experimental, ethical, communication, and laboratory standards relevant to the selected placement.

Key Points: Apply skills in research or industry; Capstone purpose

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req017
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Who supervises the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: The capstone is supervised by faculty in coordination with industry or research mentors.

Key Points: Faculty and industry supervision

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:accel003
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: When can eligible students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Option begin taking graduate courses for dual credit?

Answer: Students may begin taking graduate-level courses during their senior year of undergraduate study.

Key Points: Begin senior year; Graduate-level courses

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo002
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What laboratory skills will students develop in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students gain high-level lab skills in mammalian cell culture, molecular biology, microbiology, and protein techniques.

Key Points: Cell culture; Molecular biology; Microbiology; Protein techniques

model_answer: Core courses build foundational knowledge, while electives allow students to apply and expand that knowledge. Key Points: Core foundation; Electives expand knowledge

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

Key Points: Master biochemical, cellular, molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req008
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?

Answer: You will develop a curriculum plan with your Faculty Advisor that includes elective courses. This curriculum plan will be customized to meet your career goals.

Key Points: faculty advisor

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req018
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biologic development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics, applied immunology, DNA sequencing, tissue biology and engineering, industrial microbiology, drug development, intellectual property, clinical trials, biotechnology management and marketing, applicable regulations, and biotechnology ethics.

Key Points: biological and biochemical sciences; enhanced biomedication; molecular biology

retrieved_ids.text:

Answer: The Core Curriculum requires 13 credits.

Key Points: 13 core credits

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req007
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer:  The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transferrable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. In addition to the core lab and lecture coursework covering the major industry areas of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry, the program incorporates a core course entitled “Biotechnology Products and Regulation.” This course takes a critical look at industry from the initial stages of research and development in the biomedical sciences through the legal and regulatory stages of biotechnology product development and manufacturing. This content is key to understanding how the biotech industry functions and thus is a centerpiece in your training in our degree program. Finally, you are required to enroll in a minimum of one graduate biotech seminar course. While the specific content of the seminar courses will vary to reflect the dynamics of the ever-changing biotech field, the two typical focus areas of the semester-long seminars will be “Instrumentation in the Biotech Industry” and “Cutting edge topics in the Biotech Industry today”.

Key Points: team-based lab courses

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Full-time students can complete the program in 18 months. Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor’s degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program. Students choosing the project or internship track would undertake an internship or internships in industry, applied research in an industrial job where the student is already employed, or research in a faculty member’s laboratory at UNH. Students choosing the co-op work experience route would spend 6 months in a full-time industrial placement as part of their degree program.

Key Points: 18 months; Accelerated Master's program in 12 months

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req018
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biologic development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics, applied immunology, DNA sequencing, tissue biology and engineering, industrial microbiology, drug development, intellectual property, clinical trials, biotechnology management and marketing, applicable regulations, and biotechnology ethics.

Key Points: biological and biochemical sciences; enhanced biomedication; molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo001
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

Key Points: Master biochemical, cellular, molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees
retrieved_ids.text: Accelerated Master's. Qualified senior students at the University of New Hampshire may be admitted to an approved accelerated graduate program in the Graduate School provided they have followed normal application procedures; they must have been admitted for the semester in which they wish to enroll in courses for dual credit. A 3.20 cumulative grade point average is normally required to be considered for the program. Students are normally admitted prior to the start of their senior year. Students who have been admitted to the program may register for a maximum of 12 credits of 800-­level courses prior to completing their bachelor's degree. Such courses may, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, count toward both the bachelor's and master's degrees. Up to 8 credits, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, may count towards both the bachelor's degree and a graduate certificate. For more information and a list of eligible programs, visit: https://gradschool.unh.edu/academics/accelerated-masters-program .

Traditional full-time enrolled students will be able complete the degree in 18 months. UNH Bachelor's degree students entering into the Accelerated Master’s program as full time students will be able to complete their degree in as little as 12 months.

Key Points: 18 months; Accelerated Master's program in 12 months

retrieved_ids.text:

Key Points: regulatory and legal framework

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

Key Points: Master biochemical, cellular, molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo011
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What specialty development is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students develop core expertise in an area of biotechnology or related fields through supervised research or industrial development work.

Key Points: Develop specialty through research/industry work

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req018
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biologic development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics, applied immunology, DNA sequencing, tissue biology and engineering, industrial microbiology, drug development, intellectual property, clinical trials, biotechnology management and marketing, applicable regulations, and biotechnology ethics.

Key Points: biological and biochemical sciences; enhanced biomedication; molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req007
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer:  The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transferrable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. In addition to the core lab and lecture coursework covering the major industry areas of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry, the program incorporates a core course entitled “Biotechnology Products and Regulation.” This course takes a critical look at industry from the initial stages of research and development in the biomedical sciences through the legal and regulatory stages of biotechnology product development and manufacturing. This content is key to understanding how the biotech industry functions and thus is a centerpiece in your training in our degree program. Finally, you are required to enroll in a minimum of one graduate biotech seminar course. While the specific content of the seminar courses will vary to reflect the dynamics of the ever-changing biotech field, the two typical focus areas of the semester-long seminars will be “Instrumentation in the Biotech Industry” and “Cutting edge topics in the Biotech Industry today”.

Key Points: team-based lab courses

retrieved_ids.text:

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?

Answer: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and a Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

Key Points: 30 credits; 4 Core Curriculum courses

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo008
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What transferable professional skills are emphasized in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students will able to deploy important biotechnology industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking.

Key Points: Communication; Teamwork; Problem-solving; Strategic thinking

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req018
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biologic development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics, applied immunology, DNA sequencing, tissue biology and engineering, industrial microbiology, drug development, intellectual property, clinical trials, biotechnology management and marketing, applicable regulations, and biotechnology ethics.

Key Points: biological and biochemical sciences; enhanced biomedication; molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo001
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

Key Points: Master biochemical, cellular, molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo011
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What specialty development is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students develop core expertise in an area of biotechnology or related fields through supervised research or industrial development work.

Key Points: Develop specialty through research/industry work

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo002
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What laboratory skills will students develop in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students gain high-level lab skills in mammalian cell culture, molecular biology, microbiology, and protein techniques.

Key Points: Cell culture; Molecular biology; Microbiology; Protein techniques

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo005
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How do students engage with research literature in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: They learn to understand, analyze, evaluate, and summarize primary research literature involving biotechnology related topics.

Key Points: Analyze and summarize primary literature

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req007
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer:  The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transferrable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. In addition to the core lab and lecture coursework covering the major industry areas of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry, the program incorporates a core course entitled “Biotechnology Products and Regulation.” This course takes a critical look at industry from the initial stages of research and development in the biomedical sciences through the legal and regulatory stages of biotechnology product development and manufacturing. This content is key to understanding how the biotech industry functions and thus is a centerpiece in your training in our degree program. Finally, you are required to enroll in a minimum of one graduate biotech seminar course. While the specific content of the seminar courses will vary to reflect the dynamics of the ever-changing biotech field, the two typical focus areas of the semester-long seminars will be “Instrumentation in the Biotech Industry” and “Cutting edge topics in the Biotech Industry today”.

Key Points: team-based lab courses

Key Points: faculty advisor

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req018
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biologic development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics, applied immunology, DNA sequencing, tissue biology and engineering, industrial microbiology, drug development, intellectual property, clinical trials, biotechnology management and marketing, applicable regulations, and biotechnology ethics.

Key Points: biological and biochemical sciences; enhanced biomedication; molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req008
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?

Key Points: faculty advisor

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req007
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer:  The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transferrable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. In addition to the core lab and lecture coursework covering the major industry areas of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry, the program incorporates a core course entitled “Biotechnology Products and Regulation.” This course takes a critical look at industry from the initial stages of research and development in the biomedical sciences through the legal and regulatory stages of biotechnology product development and manufacturing. This content is key to understanding how the biotech industry functions and thus is a centerpiece in your training in our degree program. Finally, you are required to enroll in a minimum of one graduate biotech seminar course. While the specific content of the seminar courses will vary to reflect the dynamics of the ever-changing biotech field, the two typical focus areas of the semester-long seminars will be “Instrumentation in the Biotech Industry” and “Cutting edge topics in the Biotech Industry today”.

Key Points: team-based lab courses

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo004
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How will students communicate technical information in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students will be able to demonstrate the ability to communicate high-level technical information related to biotechnology in scientific writing and oral presentations to a variety of audiences.

Key Points: scientific writin; oral presentations

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo006
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How is the scientific method applied in the biotechnology: industrial and biomedical sciences (m.s.) program?

Answer: Students will be able to understand and apply the process of the scientific method, including being able to formulate hypotheses, design and conduct experiments with adequate controls to test hypotheses, interpret and evaluate data, and draw conclusions.

Key Points: formulate hypotheses; design and conduct experiments

Key Points: Bridge undergraduate and graduate study; Efficient pathway; Career preparation

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?

Answer: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and a Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

Key Points: 30 credits; 4 Core Curriculum courses

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo003
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What legal and regulatory understanding is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Successfully employ knowledge of the regulatory and legal framework that underpins the field of industrial biotechnology, including knowledge of pre-clinical and clinical product development, relevant US government regulations and laws, and intellectual property concerns.

Key Points: regulatory and legal framework

Question: What is the Accelerated Master’s Option in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Accelerated Master’s programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree.

Key Points: graduate coursework; undergraduate students

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo002
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What laboratory skills will students develop in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students gain high-level lab skills in mammalian cell culture, molecular biology, microbiology, and protein techniques.

Key Points: Cell culture; Molecular biology; Microbiology; Protein techniques

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req009
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many total program credits are composed of core, elective, and capstone work in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: The program totals 30 credits combining core, elective, and capstone work.

Key Points: 30 total credits; core; elective; capstone

retrieved_ids.text:

Answer: The Capstone Experience requires between 3 and 9 credits.

Key Points: Capstone 3–9 credits

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How is the scientific method applied in the biotechnology: industrial and biomedical sciences (m.s.) program?

Answer: Students will be able to understand and apply the process of the scientific method, including being able to formulate hypotheses, design and conduct experiments with adequate controls to test hypotheses, interpret and evaluate data, and draw conclusions.

Key Points: formulate hypotheses; design and conduct experiments

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What quantitative and data skills are emphasized in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Students will be able to demonstrate expertise in quantitative skills including basic math and statistics, use of spreadsheet or statistical software, and graphical presentation of quantitative data.

Key Points: spreadsheet or statistical software; quantitative data

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?

Answer: After completion of 9 credits in the MS Biotechnology program, students are required to enroll in at least one credit under Capstone Experience: BIOT 891, BIOT 892, BIOT 895, or BIOT 889. The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator and will be consistent with your career development plans.

Key Points: 9 credits

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req018
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biologic development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics, applied immunology, DNA sequencing, tissue biology and engineering, industrial microbiology, drug development, intellectual property, clinical trials, biotechnology management and marketing, applicable regulations, and biotechnology ethics.

Key Points: biological and biochemical sciences; enhanced biomedication; molecular biology

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the overall purpose of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Master’s Option?

Answer: It bridges undergraduate and graduate study, providing an efficient pathway to advanced biotechnology training and career preparation.

Key Points: Bridge undergraduate and graduate study; Efficient pathway; Career preparation

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo001
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

Key Points: Master biochemical, cellular, molecular biology

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:slo003
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What legal and regulatory understanding is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Successfully employ knowledge of the regulatory and legal framework that underpins the field of industrial biotechnology, including knowledge of pre-clinical and clinical product development, relevant US government regulations and laws, and intellectual property concerns.

Key Points: regulatory and legal framework

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req007
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer:  The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transferrable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. In addition to the core lab and lecture coursework covering the major industry areas of cell, molecular, and protein biochemistry, the program incorporates a core course entitled “Biotechnology Products and Regulation.” This course takes a critical look at industry from the initial stages of research and development in the biomedical sciences through the legal and regulatory stages of biotechnology product development and manufacturing. This content is key to understanding how the biotech industry functions and thus is a centerpiece in your training in our degree program. Finally, you are required to enroll in a minimum of one graduate biotech seminar course. While the specific content of the seminar courses will vary to reflect the dynamics of the ever-changing biotech field, the two typical focus areas of the semester-long seminars will be “Instrumentation in the Biotech Industry” and “Cutting edge topics in the Biotech Industry today”.

Key Points: team-based lab courses

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Full-time students can complete the program in 18 months. Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor’s degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program. Students choosing the project or internship track would undertake an internship or internships in industry, applied research in an industrial job where the student is already employed, or research in a faculty member’s laboratory at UNH. Students choosing the co-op work experience route would spend 6 months in a full-time industrial placement as part of their degree program.

Key Points: 18 months; Accelerated Master's program in 12 months

retrieved_ids.text:

Answer: The Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) requires 30 graduate credits in total.

Key Points: 30 total credits required

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: cybersecurity-engineering-ms:desc002
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?

Answer: It is designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

Key Points: Designed for working professionals; Strong interest in cybersecurity

retrieved_ids.text: Each program specifies the number of courses required for the degree.

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Master's Degree Requirements - Credits
retrieved_ids.text: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits are taken in a program other than the one in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the student's adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. Such courses must be taken for a letter grade. Petitions must include what additional requirements or expectations will be required of the student to make the course a graduate level experience. Petition requests must be made prior to enrolling in the course and are not guaranteed.

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Certificate Programs
retrieved_ids.text: Graduate certificate programs require the completion of at least 4 graduate courses for a minimum of 12 credits of graduate coursework (800- or 900-level courses) organized in a coherent and logical manner to provide knowledge and expertise relevant to a specific aspect of professional and/or personal development. All coursework in a certificate program must be taken at UNH.

retrieved_ids.title: Credit Transfer - Credit Transfer - External to UNH
retrieved_ids.text: Students may request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program. Courses must be at the graduate level and cannot have been used or be in the process of being used in earning another graduate degree or certificate or have been taken while completing a bachelor's degree. A grade of B or better must have been earned. Students must submit an External Transfer Credit Form to request that the credits be applied to their degree requirements.

retrieved_ids.text: The degree requires a minimum 30 graduate credits made up of nine core courses and culminating with a required capstone experience. The capstone involves a project custom-designed by each student (in cooperation with an advisor) to address real-world or work-related challenges in cybersecurity. Students research into the chosen challenge/problem, and then synthesize and apply their knowledge to recommend solutions or other deliverables that help address the problem.

retrieved_ids.text: The most appropriate capstone experience(s) for each program is determined by the faculty of each program. retrieved_ids.text: Requirements for non-­thesis capstone experiences must be clearly articulated by each program. retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Full-time students can complete the program in 18 months. Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor’s degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program. Students choosing the project or internship track would undertake an internship or internships in industry, applied research in an industrial job where the student is already employed, or research in a faculty member’s laboratory at UNH. Students choosing the co-op work experience route would spend 6 months in a full-time industrial placement as part of their degree program.

Key Points: 18 months; Accelerated Master's program in 12 months

retrieved_ids.title: Computing (COMP) - Computing (COMP) - COMP 892 - Applied Research Internship
retrieved_ids.text: This Applied Research Internship enhances the student's academic achievements with real-world, professional computing applied research projects at a sponsoring organization. The student is expected to apply knowledge and skills acquired through other coursework in the major to address a research question in information technology related fields under the direction of a faculty advisor and a site supervisor at the organization.

retrieved_ids.title: Computer Science (M.S.) - Computer Science (M.S.)
retrieved_ids.text: The M.S. program is designed to help students increase the breadth and depth of their computer science knowledge, strengthen their software development skills, and build their research skills. Professionally-­oriented students often complete industry internships, and the program has an outstanding job placement record for its graduates. Research­-oriented students complete an M.S. thesis under the guidance of a faculty mentor, which usually leads to publication and provides clear evidence of the developed research skills useful for obtaining a leadership position in industry or to go on to do a Ph.D. Applications are welcomed from students whose undergraduate degree is not in computer science. In this case, a well-­defined set of undergraduate prerequisites must be completed as part of the M.S. program of study.

retrieved_ids.text: Each program specifies the number of courses required for the degree.

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Master's Degree Requirements - Credits
retrieved_ids.text: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits are taken in a program other than the one in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the student's adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. Such courses must be taken for a letter grade. Petitions must include what additional requirements or expectations will be required of the student to make the course a graduate level experience. Petition requests must be made prior to enrolling in the course and are not guaranteed.

retrieved_ids.title: Credit Transfer - Credit Transfer - External to UNH
retrieved_ids.text: Students may request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program. Courses must be at the graduate level and cannot have been used or be in the process of being used in earning another graduate degree or certificate or have been taken while completing a bachelor's degree. A grade of B or better must have been earned. Students must submit an External Transfer Credit Form to request that the credits be applied to their degree requirements.

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Certificate Programs
retrieved_ids.text: Graduate certificate programs require the completion of at least 4 graduate courses for a minimum of 12 credits of graduate coursework (800- or 900-level courses) organized in a coherent and logical manner to provide knowledge and expertise relevant to a specific aspect of professional and/or personal development. All coursework in a certificate program must be taken at UNH.

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: degree-requirements:q0017
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?

Answer: Thesis Credit During their degree program, a student completing a thesis must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. Students are advised to review their program's degree requirements as the exact number of required thesis credits within each program can vary. The exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs. Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of thesis credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum. No thesis credit shall be given until the completed thesis has been approved by the thesis committee and accepted by the Graduate School. Satisfactory acceptance of the thesis will be recorded with a grade of (CR).

Key Points: Thesis Credit During their degree program, a student completing a thesis must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits.; Satisfactory acceptance of the thesis will be recorded with a grade of (CR).

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Can I transfer credits into my program?

Answer: Credit Transfer A maximum of 12 credits taken by a student prior to matriculation (internal and external combined) can be applied to a degree program. Transfer credits must be formally approved and appear on the UNH transcript in order for them to count towards the degree requirements.

Key Points: Credit Transfer A maximum of 12 credits taken by a student prior to matriculation (internal and external combined) can be applied to a degree program.

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: information-technology-ms:desc006
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Does the IT (M.S.) program require an internship?

Answer: Capitalizing on the campus location in New Hampshire's largest city and the state's corporate and financial center, the program requires an internship experience. With support from many business, technology and non-profit organizations who sponsor internships, students integrate authentic professional experiences in their academic coursework early in the program.

Key Points: Internship required

retrieved_ids.text:

retrieved_ids.text:

Key Points: Early professional experiences through internships

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: biotechnology-industrial-biomedical-sciences-ms:req001
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

Answer: Full-time students can complete the program in 18 months. Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor’s degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program. Students choosing the project or internship track would undertake an internship or internships in industry, applied research in an industrial job where the student is already employed, or research in a faculty member’s laboratory at UNH. Students choosing the co-op work experience route would spend 6 months in a full-time industrial placement as part of their degree program.

Key Points: 18 months; Accelerated Master's program in 12 months

retrieved_ids.title: Computer Science (M.S.) - Computer Science (M.S.)
retrieved_ids.text: The M.S. program is designed to help students increase the breadth and depth of their computer science knowledge, strengthen their software development skills, and build their research skills. Professionally-­oriented students often complete industry internships, and the program has an outstanding job placement record for its graduates. Research­-oriented students complete an M.S. thesis under the guidance of a faculty mentor, which usually leads to publication and provides clear evidence of the developed research skills useful for obtaining a leadership position in industry or to go on to do a Ph.D. Applications are welcomed from students whose undergraduate degree is not in computer science. In this case, a well-­defined set of undergraduate prerequisites must be completed as part of the M.S. program of study.

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: degree-requirements:q0017
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?

Answer: Thesis Credit During their degree program, a student completing a thesis must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. Students are advised to review their program's degree requirements as the exact number of required thesis credits within each program can vary. The exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs. Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of thesis credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum. No thesis credit shall be given until the completed thesis has been approved by the thesis committee and accepted by the Graduate School. Satisfactory acceptance of the thesis will be recorded with a grade of (CR).

Key Points: Thesis Credit During their degree program, a student completing a thesis must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits.; Satisfactory acceptance of the thesis will be recorded with a grade of (CR).

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Requirements - Credits
retrieved_ids.text: Each program specifies the number of courses required for the degree.

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Certificate Programs
retrieved_ids.text: Courses may be applied to only one certificate program but may also be applied to a master’s or doctoral degree program at UNH. There are no upper limits to the number of credits that may be applied to a degree program provided the courses fulfill a degree requirement.

retrieved_ids.title: Credit Transfer - Credit Transfer - External to UNH
retrieved_ids.text: Students may request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program. Courses must be at the graduate level and cannot have been used or be in the process of being used in earning another graduate degree or certificate or have been taken while completing a bachelor's degree. A grade of B or better must have been earned. Students must submit an External Transfer Credit Form to request that the credits be applied to their degree requirements.

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Master's Degree Requirements - Credits
retrieved_ids.text: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits are taken in a program other than the one in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the student's adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. Such courses must be taken for a letter grade. Petitions must include what additional requirements or expectations will be required of the student to make the course a graduate level experience. Petition requests must be made prior to enrolling in the course and are not guaranteed.

retrieved_ids.title: College Teaching (Graduate Certificate) - College Teaching (Graduate Certificate)
retrieved_ids.text: This program requires the satisfactory completion of 12 academic credits. Requirements include 8 credits in core courses and 4 credits in elective courses.

model_answer: Students can complete the program on a full-time basis and may engage in research through the thesis or project option.

retrieved_ids.text: The MS in Information Technology program is a professional graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information Technology. The program prepares students for a professional IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in a computing discipline. Offered at the University's urban campus in Manchester, a city that embraces cultural diversity, the program welcomes students from all over the word. With classes scheduled during the day and in the evening in fall, spring, and summer terms, the program gives students the flexibility to enroll full- or part-time.

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: information-technology-ms:desc006
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Does the IT (M.S.) program require an internship?

Answer: Capitalizing on the campus location in New Hampshire's largest city and the state's corporate and financial center, the program requires an internship experience. Key Points: Internship required

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: What key outcome does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program prepare graduates for?

Answer: Graduates of the Cybersecurity Engineering program are able to identify, analyze and respond to the complex information security threats that are increasingly common in today's digital landscape. You'll learn skills in core and advanced information security, preparing you to develop, integrate and evaluate secure IT systems and services for any organization.

Key Points: Secure information, communications, networks, control systems

retrieved_ids.title: Information Technology (M.S.) - Information Technology (M.S.)
retrieved_ids.text: The MS in Information Technology program is a professional graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information Technology. The program prepares students for a professional IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in a computing discipline. Offered at the University's urban campus in Manchester, a city that embraces cultural diversity, the program welcomes students from all over the word. With classes scheduled during the day and in the evening in fall, spring, and summer terms, the program gives students the flexibility to enroll full- or part-time.

retrieved_ids.title: Computer Science (M.S.) - Computer Science (M.S.)
retrieved_ids.text: The M.S. program is designed to help students increase the breadth and depth of their computer science knowledge, strengthen their software development skills, and build their research skills. Professionally-­oriented students often complete industry internships, and the program has an outstanding job placement record for its graduates. Research­-oriented students complete an M.S. thesis under the guidance of a faculty mentor, which usually leads to publication and provides clear evidence of the developed research skills useful for obtaining a leadership position in industry or to go on to do a Ph.D. Applications are welcomed from students whose undergraduate degree is not in computer science. In this case, a well-­defined set of undergraduate prerequisites must be completed as part of the M.S. program of study.

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Where is the Information Technology (M.S.) program offered and what schedule flexibility is there?

Answer: Offered at the University's urban campus in Manchester, a city that embraces cultural diversity, the program welcomes students from all over the word. With classes scheduled during the day and in the evening in fall, spring, and summer terms, the program gives students the flexibility to enroll full- or part-time.

Key Points: UNH Manchester; Day and evening, fall/spring/summer

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many thesis credits are required for a master’s thesis and how are they graded?

Answer: Students must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits; the accepted thesis is recorded with a grade of CR.

Key Points: 6–10 thesis credits; Final grade is CR after acceptance

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?

Answer: It is designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

Key Points: Designed for working professionals; Strong interest in cybersecurity

retrieved_ids.text: The M.S. in Information Technology program has two options for completion:

retrieved_ids.title: Computer Science (M.S.) - Computer Science (M.S.)
retrieved_ids.text: The M.S. program is designed to help students increase the breadth and depth of their computer science knowledge, strengthen their software development skills, and build their research skills. Professionally-­oriented students often complete industry internships, and the program has an outstanding job placement record for its graduates. Research­-oriented students complete an M.S. thesis under the guidance of a faculty mentor, which usually leads to publication and provides clear evidence of the developed research skills useful for obtaining a leadership position in industry or to go on to do a Ph.D. Applications are welcomed from students whose undergraduate degree is not in computer science. In this case, a well-­defined set of undergraduate prerequisites must be completed as part of the M.S. program of study.

retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many thesis credits are required for a master’s thesis and how are they graded?

Answer: Students must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits; the accepted thesis is recorded with a grade of CR.

Key Points: 6–10 thesis credits; Final grade is CR after acceptance

retrieved_ids.title: Gold Q&A: degree-requirements:q0017
retrieved_ids.text:
Question: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?

Answer: Thesis Credit During their degree program, a student completing a thesis must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. Students are advised to review their program's degree requirements as the exact number of required thesis credits within each program can vary. The exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs. Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of thesis credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum. No thesis credit shall be given until the completed thesis has been approved by the thesis committee and accepted by the Graduate School. Satisfactory acceptance of the thesis will be recorded with a grade of (CR).

Key Points: Thesis Credit During their degree program, a student completing a thesis must enroll in at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits.; Satisfactory acceptance of the thesis will be recorded with a grade of (CR).

Question: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?

Answer: Typically requires a 3.20 GPA; students may take up to 12 credits of 800-level courses before finishing the bachelor’s; with approval, up to 8 credits may count toward a graduate certificate; credits can count toward both bachelor’s and master’s as approved.

Key Points: 3.20 GPA normally required; Up to 12 credits at 800 level pre-bachelor’s; Up to 8 credits may count to grad certificate; Dual-counting with approvals

retrieved_ids.title: Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Master's Degree Requirements - Credits
retrieved_ids.text: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits are taken in a program other than the one in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the student's adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. Such courses must be taken for a letter grade. Petitions must include what additional requirements or expectations will be required of the student to make the course a graduate level experience. Petition requests must be made prior to enrolling in the course and are not guaranteed.

retrieved_ids.title: Graduate Courses - Graduate Courses
retrieved_ids.text: Graduate credits may be earned in courses numbered from 800 through 999, or under limited circumstances in courses numbered at the 700 level.

retrieved_ids.title: Credit Transfer - Credit Transfer
retrieved_ids.text: A maximum of 12 credits taken by a student prior to matriculation (internal and external combined) can be applied to a degree program. Transfer credits must be formally approved and appear on the UNH transcript in order for them to count towards the degree requirements.
